stem: The nurse is caring for a client with a T6 spinal cord injury who is experiencing manifestations of autonomic dysreflexia. Which interventions are MOST appropriate for the nurse to implement? Select all that apply.

itemContext.sbar: S: Mr. Jameson Blake, 48-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, reports a severe headache and blurred vision at 14:30. He is diaphoretic and anxious. A: His BP is 210/110 mmHg, HR is 52 bpm, and he has nasal congestion. He reports a full bladder sensation and a small, hard bowel movement this morning, despite being on a bowel management program. B: Admitted three weeks ago post-MVA resulting in T6 spinal cord injury. He has been stable, participating in rehab, using intermittent catheterization every 4 hours, and stool softeners daily. P: I'm concerned about autonomic dysreflexia. Requesting an order for immediate catheterization and bowel impaction check. I will monitor BP and HR every 5 minutes.

tabs.content: Docusate 100 mg PO daily, PRN for constipation. Ondansetron 4mg IV PRN for nausea. Hydralazine 10mg IV PRN for BP >180/100 mmHg.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of the bed promotes orthostatic hypotension, which helps to lower the blood pressure and reduces cerebral perfusion pressure. Assessing for bladder distention is crucial as urinary retention is a common trigger for autonomic dysreflexia. Catheterizing the client as prescribed will relieve bladder pressure, removing the noxious stimuli. Loosening tight clothing reduces external stimuli that can exacerbate the condition. Monitoring blood pressure every 5 minutes allows for close observation of the client's response to interventions and guides further treatment.
rationale.incorrect: Administering oxygen is not a primary intervention for autonomic dysreflexia unless the client's oxygen saturation is compromised; the SpO2 is 98% on room air. While documenting findings is important, it is not an initial intervention during a hypertensive crisis. Addressing the physiological emergency takes precedence.
clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention to prevent stroke, seizure, or death.
Always assess for and address the most common triggers first: bladder and bowel distention, skin pressure.
Elevate the head of the bed as the initial intervention to lower blood pressure and improve cerebral perfusion.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the elevated blood pressure and immediately selecting the antihypertensive medication without addressing the underlying cause of the autonomic dysreflexia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize identifying and alleviating the trigger for the autonomic dysreflexia before administering medications. Remember ABC's, but also think about the underlying cause of the patient's distress. Addressing the trigger will provide a more sustainable solution.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion: S: Search for the cause (bladder, bowel, skin). I: Immediate action (elevate head, loosen clothing). T: Take blood pressure. U: Utilize medications if needed. P: Prevent recurrence by teaching the patient self-care strategies.

options.text: Administer oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula.
Elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees.
Assess the client for bladder distention.
Document the findings in the electronic health record.
